description: Workshop Models - visual frameworks for understanding practice

models.title: The Threshold Range
models.headline: Your threshold is a range, not a number
models.tryThis: Track 10 doses across different contexts. Notice how the 'right' dose changes based on sleep, stress, and intention.
models.whyItWorks: Fixed dosing ignores context. Your threshold varies by 30-50% based on conditions. The range gives you precision.
models.visualDescription: A horizontal bar with three zones: Low (left, green), Sweet Spot (center, gold), High (right, orange). A marker shows where today's dose lands based on context factors.
models.keyInsight: Low threshold = subtle support. Sweet spot = optimal enhancement. High threshold = approaching perceptual. All have their place.

models.title: The Invisible Line
models.headline: The point between useful and impaired
models.tryThis: For your next 5 doses, note the moment you notice something. That's your line. Track it by batch.
models.whyItWorks: The invisible line is where threshold becomes noticeable. Staying below it = functional enhancement. Crossing it = different state entirely.
models.visualDescription: A dotted horizontal line across a gradient. Below the line: 'Sub-threshold (functional)'. Above the line: 'Perceptual (altered)'. The line itself marked 'Your invisible line'.
models.keyInsight: The line moves. It's higher when rested, lower when depleted. It varies by batch. Calibrate each time.

models.title: Context Variables
models.headline: Everything that affects your response
models.tryThis: Before your next dose, score each variable. After, rate the experience. Look for correlations over time.
models.whyItWorks: The dose is only one input. Sleep, food, stress, environment, and timing all modulate the experience. Track them all.
models.visualDescription: A wheel with 'DOSE' at center. Spokes radiating out to: Sleep, Food Timing, Stress, Environment, Time of Day, Caffeine, Exercise, Menstrual Cycle (optional). Each spoke has a slider from Low to High.
models.keyInsight: Most people underestimate sleep and overestimate dose. Get the context right and the dose becomes secondary.

models.title: The Carryover Effect
models.headline: Yesterday's dose affects today's sensitivity
models.tryThis: After dosing two days in a row, notice the difference. The second dose almost always feels weaker. That's carryover.
models.whyItWorks: 5-HT2A receptors downregulate rapidly. A dose today means reduced sensitivity tomorrow. The app calculates this for you.
models.visualDescription: A timeline showing Day 1 (dose) with full color, Day 2 (60% color), Day 3 (80% color), Day 4+ (full color again). Arrow showing 'sensitivity returning'.
models.keyInsight: Clear carryover = full sensitivity. Mild carryover = 10-15% reduction. Moderate = 20-25%. High = consider rest.

models.title: The Breathing Room Model
models.headline: The gap between stimulus and response
models.tryThis: Next time you notice an emotional reaction, see if you can name the gap before you respond. That's the room.
models.whyItWorks: Microdosing doesn't create change. It creates space where you can see your patterns before acting on them. The room is where choice lives.
models.visualDescription: A simple diagram: [STIMULUS] → (gap labeled 'Breathing Room') → [RESPONSE]. The gap is highlighted.
models.keyInsight: The goal isn't to feel different. It's to have more room between what happens and how you react.

models.title: The Protocol Cycle
models.headline: Dose days, transition days, integration days
models.tryThis: Plan your week with all three phases. Dose days for activation. Transition days for processing. Integration days for application.
models.whyItWorks: The real work happens between doses. Integration days are when insights become changes. Don't skip them.
models.visualDescription: A circular diagram divided into three sections: 'DOSE' (orange, small slice), 'TRANSITION' (yellow, medium slice), 'INTEGRATION' (green, large slice). Arrows showing flow.
models.keyInsight: If you're only tracking dose days, you're missing most of the practice. The integration phase is where transformation lives.

models.title: Direction Over Destination
models.headline: A compass points north, it doesn't take you there
models.tryThis: Reframe your intention from 'I want to feel X' to 'I'm pointed toward X'. Notice how this changes your relationship to outcomes.
models.whyItWorks: Destinations create attachment to outcomes. Directions create orientation without grasping. The compass metaphor is the core of this practice.
models.visualDescription: A compass with needle pointing toward 'NORTH STAR' (labeled with user's direction). The path is winding, not straight.
models.keyInsight: You can be pointed in the right direction while experiencing difficulty. The direction is what matters, not the terrain.

models.title: Conditions vs. Signals
models.headline: What's around you vs. what's inside you
models.tryThis: In your next check-in, clearly separate external conditions (load, noise, schedule) from internal signals (energy, clarity, stability).
models.whyItWorks: Most trackers conflate environment and inner state. Separating them reveals which conditions create which signals for YOU specifically.
models.visualDescription: Two concentric circles. Outer circle: 'CONDITIONS' (external, environment). Inner circle: 'SIGNALS' (internal, felt sense). Arrows showing influence between them.
models.keyInsight: High external load doesn't always mean low internal stability. Some people thrive under pressure. Track your patterns.
